cons: Nothing that I can think of

pros: Good benefits Good pay Able to provide lots of different support to family, children and youth
cons: Top down management style Supervisors concerned more with looking good rather then supporting front line staff Front line staff encourage to lie to upper management Lack of follow through on their own driving values and principles

pros: I have received an annual raise each year since starting three years ago. There is a lot of respect for personal preferences, idea sharing, and teamwork. People are also very supportive and generally genuinely kind and fun.
cons:
The ratio of time needed drive time around the city of Calgary is not considered and factored into your caseload numbers which results in continuous over time due to traffic or crises. They don’t pay overtime and the averaging agreement requires you to take time off instead which can be near impossible to do while continuing the balance at a deficit. 
I don’t love the way the responded during the summer 2021 part of the pandemic as they refused to continue following health protocols despite best known resources under the excuse that the government isn’t requiring them to have restrictions at that time - despite that we have close personal contact with clients, teach and gushed using hand over hand methods, drive our clients and help them with exercise. But they didn’t want to enforce a mask policy on employees or clients despite concerns from many staff. 
Middle management turnover is high which can be frustrating and often new leadership seems underprepared and overwhelmed.

pros:
Great work environment
Great community setting
Wonderful management
cons: Unustainable wages for supporting my family

review_title: A great environment with a lot of training opportunities
job_title: Outreach Worker in Medicine Hat, AB
pros: The supervisors are knowledgeable and supportive. The upper management is very down-to-earth. You're treated like a person.
cons: Job security is a bit dicey depending on which program you're working under. This is due to non-profit and funding matters that McMan doesn't have control of.
Not-for profit work- children's services funding model not terribly compatible with values of the agency. Challenging and emotional work

pros: Great pay, supportive leadership and team members, flexible schedule.
cons: On-call once a year, required to answer emergency phone 24/7 for a week.

job_title: Community Resource Worker in Edmonton, AB
pros: One of the best companies I have worked with so far in Edmonton. Great pay and good benefits
cons: No bonuses at the end of the year and some working hours are odd

review_title: Great, but could use some work
pros: Great resources, good support, they attract great staff.
cons: Conservative, stays with the old, doesn't necessarily change to take on new ideas, stuck in old school even though it could be toxic to the rest of the workplace

pros: The pay is alright and there are some decent people working there.
cons: There seems to be a lack of cohesion between houses and the mandate of the agency itself.

pros: This agency hires good people into frontline positions that are resilient, creative, caring and tireless.
cons: This agency's leadership team isn't communicative, nor do they seek out the opinions and concerns of the frontline staff.

job_title: Youth Care Worker in Edmonton, AB
pros: Mcman was very accommodating. Great organization to learn, develop and prosper.

pros: McMan employs a diverse, young team
cons: Low wages, and a constant shuffle of management. Most people felt like they were on the cusp of a job loss at any given time.
